subject: Re: [junit] Re: junit 4 expected= subclass change
msgSnippet: ... There must be loads of examples of this in the Java IO classes, which declare throwing IOException, but how many subclases of IOException are there?
messageBody:
On 10/02/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Ben Maurer wrote:
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@...> wrote:
> > >
> > > Ben,
> > >
> > > Thank you for the feedback. We went around on this. It seems there
> > are two
> > > cases:
> > >
> > > 1) I am throwing an exception but I want to make it more specific so
> > I throw
> > > a subclass (Exception -> IllegalArgumentException). No catch clauses
> > care
> > > about the more-specific exception. If expected is looking for a
> precise
> > > class, a bunch of tests will break even though the code still works.
> >
> > I've never seen an api that says "when you do X, we will throw a
> > random type of exception (though it will derive from Y)"
>
> I hope you have! The Liskov Substitution Principle says that I'm allowed
> to throw an exception I want, as long as it is an instanceof the one I
> declare I'm going to throw. This is why I don't like possibly throwing
> different exceptions in each other's inheritance tree. (I don't treat
> RuntimeException as an instanceof Exception for the purposes of this
> line of reasoning. To me, that was a heinous mistake on Java's part.
> They should each extend Throwable or some other common base class.)
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
> Your guide to software craftsmanship
> JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> 2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice



There must be loads of examples of this in the Java IO classes, which
declare throwing IOException, but how many subclases of IOException are
there?
